description.original_author: openEHR Archetype Editorial Group / Ocean Informatics

details.purpose: Generic entry for an anatomical pathology test or histopathology test . This may be used for very simple reporting formats but will often be specialised or extended via the Structured Detail slots.
details.use:
Normally used only as the basis for further specialisation but is suitable for very simple tests with only a free text conclusion. Will generally be used in combination with archetypes representing other parts of the laboratory test ordering and processing process to form a full lab test report within a Composition.
Specimen slots are available in a number of positions to reflect the variation in pathology reporting styles.
details.misuse: Do not use for standard itemised value-driven lab tests such as haematology and biochemistry- use OBSERVATION.lab_test. Do not use for microbiology - use OBSERVATION.lab_test-microbiology.

items.items: A subtype of the histopthological result.
A single set of macroscopic pathology findings.
Narrative text recorded at the time of specimen macroscopic dissection.
Details of the macroscopic specimen being reported.
Further structured detail concerning macroscopic findings
Single set of microscopic pathology findings. Usually equates to a single specimen.
Narrative text recorded at the time of specimen microscopic examination.
Further structured detail of microscopic findings, often disease or organ specific.
Macroscopic findings - more than one set of findings may be recorded.
Microscopic findings - more than one set of findings may be recorded.
General comment or description about macroscopy findings.
General comment or description about microscopy findings as a whole.
Confirmation, or otherwise, that the tissue or structure referred to by this macroscopic finding is present in the specimen for analysis.
The anatomical structure or tissue is present.
The anatomical structure or tissue is absent
Details of pathological staging, particularly for malignancy.
Details of size of one or more components of a single microscopy report e.g details of one or more tumour locations within a single tissue such as lung
Details of the size or other physical properties of the microscopic finding.
Details of the anatomical location of the microscopic finding being described.

To record the result of a laboratory test which may be used to record a single valued test but will often be specialised or templated to represent multiple value or 'panel' tests. This archetype also acts as the parent for specialisations appropriate for more specific laboratory tests microbiology, histopathology.

Specific identifier for this lab test. e.g. Full blood count , blood glucose, urine microbiology. May equate to the result name for a single value result. Commonly a coded term e.g from LOINC or SNOMED-CT.
Representations of the whole test in mutlimedia e.g image, audio, video.
Unique identifiers used in delivery of the care process.
Demographic details of the laboratory with responsibility for the test. Details of secondary laboratories may also be included.
This is an initial or interim result - further updates are anticipated
This is the final result. No further alterations are anticipated
This is a supplememtary result in addition to the Interim result
This is a Correction which should replace any previous results
An overall interpretative comment on this test.
The ID assigned to the order by the order requester. Equivalent to the NEHTA Requester Order Identifier.
The ID assigned to the test order by the order filler, usually by the (LIS) Laboratory Information System. Equivalent to the DICOM Accession Number and NEHTA Laboratory Request Identifier.
Details of the specimen being reported where all individual results are derived from the same specimen
The identifier given to the laboratory test result of a pathology investigation.
The status of the lab test as a whole.
The date and/or time that the result was issued for the recorded test status.
The date and time related to the results status is useful for version control and cumulative results for the report.
The type of high-level diagnostic service e.g. biochemistry, haematology.
Conclusions or 'pathological diagnoses' for the whole test.
A conclusion or 'pathological diagnosis' for this individual microscopic finding.
Slot to allow an annotation to be added to a particular test result at run-time. Generally unused in this specialisation.
